channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Obama Says Mullah Mansour, Taliban Leader, Was Killed in U.S. Strike
item.media:description: Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour, in an undated photo.
item.description: President Obama released a statement calling the killing of Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour in an American drone strike in Pakistan “an important milestone.”
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Vietnam Arms Embargo to Be Fully Lifted, Obama Says in Hanoi
item.description: The president’s announcement that the United States was “fully lifting” the decades-old ban on lethal weapons sales came at a news conference in Hanoi.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: Arriving in Vietnam, Obama Aims to Lure It Away From China
item.description: Vietnam may grant U.S. warships access to its ports, and Washington seems certain to widen exceptions to its longtime arms embargo and may end it altogether.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Israel Allows Building Supplies to Enter Gaza Again
item.media:description: Trucks loaded with bags of cement on Monday at the Kerem Shalom border crossing between Israel and southern Gaza.
item.description: The Israeli authorities lifted a suspension that had blocked work for more than a month on thousands of houses destroyed in the 2014 summer war.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: West Bank Journal: A Window Into West Bank’s ‘Wildest, Most Violent’ Areas
item.media:description: Hanamel Dorfman, 21, beside the rubble of a house that was demolished this month by the Israeli authorities in Yishuv Hadaat, a Jewish settlement outpost in the West Bank.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: A documentary by the Israeli-American filmmaker Shimon Dotan, “The Settlers,” scheduled to be shown in Israel for the first time on Monday, examines a fringe group known as the “hilltop youth.”
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Entrusted to Save Brazil: The Party That Ruined Rio
item.media:description: Brazil’s new leader, Michel Temer, promised a new day of “national salvation,” but his party has a record of problems in Rio de Janeiro, where it wields great power.
item.description: The country’s new governing party has long wielded great power in this oil-rich state — a place afflicted by crime, graft, pollution and economic woes.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Galápagos Islands Gain a New Guardian as Ecuador Moves to Protect the Park
item.media:description: Africa Berdonces, 30, is the new director of Galápagos National Park and Marine Reserve.
item.description: Africa Berdonces, 30, is the new director of Galápagos National Park and Marine Reserve, one of the world’s most significant environmental posts.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH B. TREASTER

item.title: Mexico Prepares to Counter ‘the Trump Emergency’
item.media:description: Graffiti ridiculing Donald J. Trump on a section of the border fence separating the United States and Mexico outside Tijuana.
item.description: A number of prominent Mexicans are worried about what a victory by Donald J. Trump in the presidential campaign could mean for the complex relationship between the United States and Mexico.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Austrian Far-Right Candidate Norbert Hofer Narrowly Loses Presidential Vote
item.media:description: Norbert Hofer at a Freedom Party gathering in Vienna on Sunday.
item.description: Mr. Hofer, a 45-year-old aeronautics engineer, lost to Alexander Van der Bellen, an independent backed by the Green Party.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: In Austrian Election, Far-Right Candidate Is Deadlocked With Rival
item.description: Norbert Hofer of the Freedom Party was in a virtual dead heat with Alexander Van der Bellen, a former Green Party leader, in the presidential election on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Angelina Jolie Will Be Visiting Professor at London School of Economics
item.media:description: The actress Angelina Jolie Pitt, who is also a special envoy for the United Nations refugee agency, was in London last week.
item.description: The actress will be a guest lecturer in a master’s program that starts taking applicants in the fall at one of Britain’s most renowned institutions.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: David Cameron Says Leaving E.U. Would Hobble British Economy
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, left, and George Osborne, the chancellor of the Exchequer, addressed employees at the headquarters of a home-improvement chain in southern England on Monday.
item.description: The prime minister, citing a Treasury report, warned of a recession, a decline in the value of the pound, and half a million lost jobs.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Suicide Attacks Hit 2 Syrian Cities in Assad Stronghold, Killing Scores
item.media:description: The site of a suicide bombing in the coastal town of Tartus, Syria, on Monday.
item.description: The coordinated assaults on bus stations and part of a hospital brought the horrors of the country’s civil war into a region that had been relatively safe.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and MAHER SAMAAN

item.title: Sinosphere: Political Light Installation on Hong Kong Skyscraper Is Pulled
item.description: Organizers said they weren’t told that the display would have a countdown to 2047, when China’s promise of a high degree of autonomy for Hong Kong expires.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Iraqi Leader Announces Offensive on ISIS-Controlled City of Falluja
item.media:description: Iraqi forces advanced toward Falluja on Monday, in an operation aimed at retaking the city from the Islamic State.
item.description: Any ground battle to liberate the city, a stronghold of Sunni extremism that fell to the Islamic State more than two years ago, is likely to be long and bloody.
item.dc:creator: FALIH HASSAN and TIM ARANGO
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Thailand Dormitory Fire Kills at Least 17 Girls, Official Says
item.media:description: Rescue workers removed an injured student early Monday after a fire broke out at a school dormitory in northern Thailand.
item.description: The victims, ages 6 to 12, died after the blaze broke out around 11 p.m. at a school in northern Thailand, an Interior Ministry official said.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Taiwan Drops Charges Against Protesters in Government Sit-In
item.media:description: Riot police officers clashing with protesters outside Taiwan’s cabinet building, in Taipei, the capital, in 2014.
item.description: The demonstrators had been charged in the takeover of Taiwan’s cabinet building in 2014 as part of the Sunflower Movement, a protest over closer China ties.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: 3 Mount Everest Climbers Die on Their Way Down
item.media:description: More than 250 people have died trying to climb Everest since the first recorded ascent in 1953.
item.description: An Australian woman, a Dutch man and an Indian man were believed to have been killed by altitude sickness.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Kang Sok-ju, Key Nuclear Negotiator for North Korea, Dies at 76
item.media:description: Kang Sok-ju, a top North Korean foreign policy aide, in an undated photo.
item.description: Mr. Kang, a top foreign policy aide of Kim Jong-il, was known for a 1994 agreement with the United States that fell apart after accusations that North Korea was secretly pursuing uranium enrichment.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Memo From France: French Lawmaker’s Fall Over Harassment Claims May Hold Lesson for Men: Behave
item.media:description: A group of women demonstrated against the sexual harassment of women in front of the National Assembly in Paris this month. The Assembly’s vice president, Denis Baupin, resigned amid accusations of misbehavior.
item.description: That message came through clearly when several women stepped forward with accusations that forced a National Assembly leader to resign.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: White House Letter: Obama Braces for Donald Trump Questions From World Leaders
item.media:description: President Obama at a briefing at the White House in early May, when he said that Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign should receive “genuine scrutiny” and that the race should not be treated like “a reality show.”
item.description: President Obama’s private discussions at the Group of 7 summit in Japan are likely to cover a topic not on the agenda: Mr. Trump’s chances of becoming president.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: John Kerry and Aung San Suu Kyi: A Milestone Meeting in Myanmar, Tempered by Questions
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and Secretary of State John Kerry at a news conference on Sunday in Naypyitaw, Myanmar.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Nyein Chan Naing
item.description: Topics included Myanmar’s brutal treatment of a Muslim minority group and on the delicate question of whether Burmese military leaders once had a program in place to build a nuclear weapon.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Greek Lawmakers Narrowly Approve Austerity Legislation
item.media:description: The Greek finance minister Euclid Tsakalotos, left, and Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras at the debate in Parliament on Sunday.
item.description: The legislation includes higher taxes on coffee, alcohol, fuel and other goods and a mechanism to cut state spending if Greece misses its budget targets.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Egypt Sends Submersible in Search for EgyptAir Jet’s Black Boxes
item.media:description: Prayers for the victims of EgyptAir Flight 804 at Al-Boutrossiya Church in Cairo on Sunday.
item.description: The submersible, sent to help find the wreckage of Flight 804, joined an international flotilla of ships and surveillance planes scouring a section of the Mediterranean.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Party in Turkey Elects Binali Yildirim, Erdogan Ally, as Prime Minister
item.media:description: Binali Yildirim arrived at the Justice and Development Party congress in Ankara, Turkey, on Sunday. Mr. Yildirim, a longtime ally of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, was unanimously elected prime minister.
item.description: Binali Yildirim replaces Ahmet Davutoglu, who abruptly stepped down this month after a public rift with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Marco Pannella, Italian Champion of Civil Liberties, Dies at 86
item.media:description: Marco Pannella, left, in 1981. As the leader of Italy’s Radical Party, he championed the rights of women, gay people and inmates.
item.description: As the co-founder of Italy’s Radical Party, Mr. Pannella campaigned to legalize abortion, divorce and marijuana in his predominantly Catholic country.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: In China, Government Workers Push Rosy, Diverting Views Online
item.media:description: Men at an Internet bar in Beijing. China’s push to polish its image at home and abroad has gained new traction under President Xi Jinping.
item.description: A new study focuses on China’s “Fifty Cent Party,” who tout Beijing’s views online and make up a major part of its effort to control its image.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Iraq Begins Operation to Retake Falluja From ISIS
item.description: Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi announced the start of a military campaign to retake the city from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Taliban Chief Targeted by Drone Strike in Pakistan, Signaling a U.S. Shift
item.media:description: The wreckage of a vehicle that Mullah Akhtar Muhammad Mansour was said to be traveling in near the Afghan border in the Pakistani province of Baluchistan on Saturday.
item.description: The strike, which Afghan intelligence said had killed the leader, indicated a major break with precedent as the United States circumvented Pakistan, which has been unable to broker peace talks with the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: What in the World: A Uniquely Korean Household Worry
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photo by donnichols/istock
item.description: Across South Korea, many people believe a common household appliance can kill if left on too long.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: What in the World: For This Green Smoothie, the First Ingredient Is Frog
item.media:credit: Illustration by Alvaro Dominguez; Photo by Hintau Aliaksei/Shutterstock
item.description: In Peru and Bolivia, drinks made from the endangered Titicaca water frog are promoted as a cure for many ailments, without scientific support.
item.dc:creator: EVAN GERSHKOVICH

item.title: What in the World: China Offers Airport Security for Women, and Their Makeup
item.description: “Female Only” security lines are at four airports, in part so women are not frisked by men, but also because cosmetics require greater scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Australia’s Offshore Cruelty
item.media:description: Protesting in March outside the office of Australia’s immigration minister in Brisbane.
item.description: Scrap a policy that condemns refugees to a desperate and hopeless limbo.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Bertie Wooster v. Donald Trump
item.media:description: A protest in Birmingham, England, in February.
item.description: Britons like to believe that comic genius is protection from tyranny. They shouldn’t be too complacent.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW D’ANCONA

item.title: Editorial: The Left on the Run in Latin America
item.description: As leftist statesmen fall out of favor, a new generation of leaders must learn from the past to chart out a more prosperous future.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Mao and Me: A Beijing Correspondent Reflects
item.media:description: Mao's portrait hangs in many cars in China, a talisman against accidents. This one hangs in the car of Chen Lei, a driver for a Russian bank. Taken in Beijing on May 18. 2016.
item.description: On the 50th anniversary of the Cultural Revolution, Didi Kirsten Tatlow knows she’s not the only person in China who’s dreaming about the Chairman.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN

item.title: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
item.media:description: A civilian evacuated a baby on Friday from a site that had been hit by airstrikes in a rebel-controlled area of Aleppo, Syria. Inhabitants of the city carry on with work and school despite fighting that has killed more than 200 civilians in the past week.
item.description: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
